What book is The movie Diamonds Are Forever based on?

The movieDiamonds Are Forever is based on the bookDiamonds are Foreverwritten by  Ian Fleming

Diamonds are ForeverPublished by Pickle Partners Publishing - 7/11/2017

JAMES BOND JOINS THE WORLD’S MOST RUTHLESS JEWEL RING... “We’re going to find out who you are and who you work for and what you know....IF you think you can hold out on us you’re wrong, dead wrong.” Jack Spang spoke to James Bond gently...menacingly. Two hooded men entered the room and sat opposite the secret agent. They put down football boots beside them and started to unlace their shoes. Spang spoke again. “We’ll make it a Brooklyn stomping. Eighty per center. Okay with you...Mr. Bond?” The Spangled Mob hires undercover agent James Bond to smuggle diamonds into America, and the ace British spy finds himself partners in crime with the most tantalizing female he’s ever encountered—Tiffany Case, hotter than stolen “ice,” as surprising as sudden death.

written byIan Fleming

Ian Fleming's Diamonds are Forever

written byIan Fleming

1/1/1987

Ian Fleming and the Politics of Ambivalence

written byIan Kinane

Published by Bloomsbury Publishing - 4/8/2021

Previously considered an avowed nationalist, this book explores how Ian Fleming's writings and his representational politics contain an implicit resistance to imperial rhetoric. Through an examination of Fleming's Jamaica-set novels Live and Let Die, Dr. No, and The Man with the Golden Gun, as well as the later film adaptations of these novels, Ian Kinane reveals Fleming's deep ambivalence to British decolonisation and to wider Anglo-Caribbean relations. Offered here is a crucial insight into the public imagination during the birth of modern British multiculturalism that encompasses broader links between Fleming's writings on race and the representation of early British-Jamaican cultural relations. By exploring the effects of racial representation in these popular works, Kinane connects the novels to more contemporary concerns regarding migration and the ways in which the misrepresentation of cultures, races, and peoples has led to fraught and contentious global geo-political relations as figured in the fictional icon, James Bond.

Blood on the Stone

written byIan Smillie

Published by Anthem Press - 1/1/2010

Africa's diamond wars took four million lives. 'Blood on the Stone' tells the story of how diamonds came to be so dangerous, describing the great diamond cartel and a dangerous pipeline leading from war-torn Africa to the glittering showrooms of Paris, London and New York. It describes the campaign that forced an industry and more than 50 governments to create a global control mechanism, and it provides a sobering prognosis on its future.

Did you know that the movie Diamonds Are Forever is based on the book Diamonds are Forever?

James Bond's mission is to find out who has been smuggling diamonds, which are not re-appearing. He adopts another identity in the form of Peter Franks. He joins up with Tiffany Case, and acts as if he is smuggling the diamonds, but everyone is hungry for these diamonds. He also has to avoid Mr. Wint and Mr. Kidd, the dangerous couple who do not leave anyone in their way. Ernst Stavro Blofeld isn't out of the question. He may have changed his looks, but is he linked with the heist? And if he is, can Bond finally defeat his ultimate enemy.

  • Internet Movie Database:  6.6/10
  • Rotten Tomatoes:  64%
  • Metacritic:  59/100
